titleStmt.title: The True Tragedy of Richard Duke of York: a machine-readable transcription of the 1595 Octavo

publicationStmt.authority: Hugh Craig, Newcastle, 2008; VARDed and checked September, 2017

sourceDesc.p: Electronic text from Internet Shakespeare Editions, accessed 19 August 2008. Checked against Early English Books 1475-1640 microfilm copy of STC 21006

editorialDecl.p: l analysis - elected part-of-sp suffixes as entities

Richard Duke of York Warwick Edward Earl of March afterwards King Edward Montague Richard afterwards Duke of Gloucester Duke of Norfolk King Henry Northumberland Clifford Westmorland George later Duke of Clarence Messenger Queen Prince Sir John Tutor Rutland Messenger First Soldier Second Soldier Keeper Lady Elizabeth Grey King Louis Characters speaking together Earl of Oxford Lady Bona Post Hastings Huntsman Lord Rivers Mayor of York Somerset Sommerfield Post from Oxford Post from Montague

langUsage.p: l The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

front.titlePart: The true Tragedie of Richard Duke of Yorke, and the death of good King Henrie the Sixt, with the whole contention between the two Houses Lancaster and Yorke, as it was sundry times acted by the Right Honourable the Earl of Pembrooke his seruants. Printed at London by P.Saint. for Thomas Millington, and are to be sold at his shop under Saint Peters Church in Cornwal. 1595.

div2.stage: Enter Richard Duke of Yorke, The Earle of Warwicke, The Duke of Norffolke, Marquis Montague, Edward Earle of March, Crookeback Richard, and the yong Earle of Rutland, with Drumme and Souldiers, with white Roses in their hats.

sp.speaker: Warwike.
sp.l: I Wonder how the king escaped our hands.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Whilst we pursued the horsemen
of the North,
He slyly stole away and left his men:
Whereat the great Lord of Northumland,
Whose warlike ears could never brooke retreat,
Charged our maine battle's front, and therewith him
Lord Stafford and Lord Clifford all abreast
Brake in and were by the hands of common Soldiers slain.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lord Staffords father Duke of Buckingham,
Is either slain or wounded dangerously,
I cleft his Beaver with a downright blow:
Father that this is true behold his blood.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And brother here is the Earl of Wiltshires
Blood, whom I encountered as the battles joined.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: What is your grace dead my Lord. of Summerset?

sp.speaker: Norf.
sp.l: Such hope have all the line of Iohn of Gawnt.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Thus do I hope to shape king Henries head.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And so do I victorious prince of Yorke,
Before I see thee seated in that throne
Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,
I vow by heavens these eyes shall never close.
This is the palace of that fearful king,
And that the regal chair? Possess it Yorke:
For this is thine and not king Henries heirs.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Assist me then sweet Warwike, and I will:
For hither are we broken in by force.

sp.speaker: Norf.
sp.l: We will all assist thee, and he that flies shall die.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Thanks gentle Norffolke. Stay by me my Lords,
and soldiers stay you here and lodge this night:

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And when the king comes offer him no
Violence, unless he seek to put us out by force.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Armed as we be, let us stay within this house?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The bloody parliament shall this be called,
unless Plantagenet Duke of Yorke be king
And bashful Henrie be deposed, whose cowardice
Hath made us by-words to our enemies.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Then leave me not my Lords: for now I mean
To take possession of my right.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Neither the king, nor him that loves him best,
The proudest bird that holds up Lancaster.
Dares stir a wing if Warwike shake his bells.
I will plant Plantagenet: and root him out who dares?
Resolve thee Richard: Claim the English crown.

div2.stage: Enter king Henrie the sixt, with the Duke of Excester, The Earle of Northumberland, the Earle of Westmerland and Clifford, the Earle of Cumberland, with red Roses in their hats.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Look Lordings where the sturdy rebel sits,
Even in the chair of state: belike he means
Backed by the power of Warwike that false peer,
To aspire unto the crown, and reign as king.
Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father.
And thine Clifford: and you both have vowed revenge,
on him, his sons, his favourites, and his friends.

sp.speaker: Northu.
sp.l: And if I be not, heavens be revenged on me.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: The hope thereof, makes Clifford mourn in steel.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: What? shall we suffer this, let us pull him down.
My hart for anger breaks, I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be patient gentle Earl of Westmerland.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Patience is for poltroons such as he
He durst not sit there had your father lived?
My gracious Lord: here in the Parliament,
Let us assail the family of Yorke.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Well hast thou spoken cousin, be it so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O know you not the City favours them,
And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: But when the Duke. is slain, they will quickly fly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Far be it from the thoughts of Henries hart,
To make a shambles of the parliament house.
Cousin of Exeter, words, frowns, and threats,
Shall be the wars that Henrie means to use.
Thou factious duke of Yorke, descend my throne,
I am thy sovereign.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Thou art deceived: I am thine.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: For shame come down he made thee Pence. of
York.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: It was mine inheritance as the kingdom is.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Exeter thou art a traitor to the crown.
In following this usurping Henry.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Whom should he follow but his natural king.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: True Clif. and that is Richard Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And shall I stand while thou sittest in my
throne?

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Content thyself it must and shall be so.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Be Duke of Lancaster, let him be king.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Why? he is both king and Duke of Lancaster,
And that the Earl of Westmerland shall maintain.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And Warwike shall disprove it. You forget
That we are those that chaste you from the field
And slew your father, and with colours spread,
Marched through the City to the palace gates.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No Warwike I remember it to my grief,
And by his soul thou and thy house shall rue it.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Plantagenet of thee and of thy sons,
Thy kinsmen and thy friends, I will have more lives,
Than, drops of blood were in my father's veins.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Urge it no more, lest in revenge thereof,
I send thee Warwike such a messenger,
As shall revenge his death before I stir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Poor Clifford, how I scorn thy worthless threats

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Will ye we show our title to the crown,
Or else our swords shall plead it in the field?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What title hast thou traitor to the Crown?
Thy father was as thou art Duke of Yorke,
Thy grandfather Roger Mortimer earl of March,
I am the son of Henrie the Fifth who tamed the French,
And made the Dolphin stoop, and seized upon their
Towns and provinces.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Talk not of France since thou hast lost it all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Lord protector lost it and not I,
When I was crowned I was but nine months old.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: You are old enough now and yet methinks
you lose,
Father tear the Crown from the Usurper's head.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Do so sweet father, set it on your head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good brother as thou lovest and honourest arms,
Let us fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sound drums and trumpets and the king will fly.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Peace sons:

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Peace thou and give king Henry leave to
speak.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah Plantagenet, why seekest thou to depose
me?
Are we not both both Plantagenets by birth,
And from two brothers lineally descent?
Suppose by right and equity thou be king,
Thinkst thou that I will leave my kingly seat
Wherein my father and my grandsire sat?
No, first shall war unpeople this my realm,
I and our colours often borne in France,
And now in England to our hearts' great sorrow
Shall be my winding sheet, why faint you Lords?
My title is better far than his.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Prove it Henrie and thou shalt be king?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Henrie the fourth by conquest got the
Crown.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: It was by rebellion against his sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know not what to say my title is weak,
Tell me may not a king adopt an heir?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then am I lawful king For Richard
The second in the view of many Lords
Resigned the Crown to Henrie the fourth,.
Whose heir my Father was, and I am his.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: I tell thee he rose against him being his
Sovereign, and made him to resign the crown perforce.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Suppose my Lord he did it unconstrained,
Think you that were prejudicial to the Crown?

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: No, for he could not so resign the Crown,
But that the next heir must succeed and reign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou against us, Duke of Exceter?

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All will revolt from me and turn to him.

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Plantagenet for all the claim thou layest,
Think not king Henry shall be thus deposed?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Deposed he shall be in despite of thee.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Tush Warwike, Thou art deceived? it is not thy
Southern powers of Essex, Suffolke, Norffolke, and of
Kent that makes thee thus presumptuous and proud,
Can set the Duke up in despite of me.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: King Henrie be thy title right or wrong,
Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence.
May that ground gape and swallow me alive,
Where I do kneel to him that slew my father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Clifford, how thy words revive my soul.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Henry of Lancaster resign thy crown.
What mutter you? or what conspire you Lords?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do right unto this princely Duke of Yorke,
Or I will fill the house with armed men,
And over the chair of state where now he sits,
Wright up his title with thy usurping blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Warwike, hear me speak.
Let me but reign in quiet whilst I live.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs
And thou shalt reign in quiet whilst thou livest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Convey the soldiers hence, and then I will.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Captain conduct them into Tuthill fields.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: What wrong is this unto the Prince your son?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What good is this for England and himself?

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Base, fearful, and despairing Henry.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How hast thou wronged both thyself and us?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: I cannot stay to hear these Articles.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Nor I, Come cousin let us go tell the Queen.

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Be thou a pray unto the house of Yorke,
And die in bands for this unkingly deed.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome,
Or live in peace abandoned and despised.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: They seek revenge, and therefore will not
yield my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah Exeter?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why should you sigh my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not for myself Lord Warwike, but my son;
Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit.
But be it as it may: I here entail the Crown
To thee and to thine heirs, conditionally,
That here thou take thine oath, to cease these civil
Broils, and whilst I live to honour me as thy king
and Sovereign.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: That oath I willingly take and will perform.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Long live king Henry. Plantagenet embrace
him?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And long live thou and all thy forward sons.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Now Yorke and Lancaster are reconciled.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes,

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: My Lord I will take my leave, for I will to Wakefield
To my castle.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And I will keep London with my soldiers.

sp.speaker: Norf
sp.l: And I will to Norffolke with my followers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And I to the sea from whence I came.

div2.stage: Enter the Queene and the Prince.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: My Lord here comes the Queen, I will steal away.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Nay stay, or else I follow thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be patient gentle Queen, and then I will stay.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What patience can there? ah timorous man,
Thou hast undone thyself, thy son, and me,
And given our rights unto the house of Yorke.
Art thou a king and wilt be forced to yield?
Had I been there, the soldiers should have tossed
Me on their lances' points, before I would have
Granted to their wills. The Duke is made
Protector of the land: Stern Fawconbridge
Commands the narrow seas. And thinkst thou then.
To sleep secure? I here divorce me Henry
From thy bed, until that Act of Parliament
Be recalled, wherein thou yieldest to the house of Yorke.
The Northern Lords that have forsworn thy colours,
Will follow mine if once they see them spread,
And spread they shall unto thy deep disgrace.
Come son, let us away and leave him here alone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Thou hast spoke too much already , therefore be still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gentle son Edwarde, wilt thou stay with me?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Aye, to be murdered by his enemies.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: When I return with victory from the field.
I will see your Grace, till then I will follow her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor Queen, her love to me and to the prince
Her son,
Makes her in fury thus forget herself.
Revenged may she be on that accursed Duke.
Come cousin of Exeter, stay thou here,
For Clifford and those Northern Lords be gone
I fear towards Wakefield, to disturb the Duke.

div2.stage: Enter Edward, and Richard, and Montague.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Brother and cousin Montague, give me leave to
speak.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay, I can better play the Orator.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But I have reasons strong and forceable.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: How now sons what at a jar amongst yourselves,?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No father, but a sweet contention, about that
which concerns yourself and us, The crown of England father.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: The crown boy, why Henry is yet alive,
And I have sworn that he shall reign in quiet till
His death.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: But I would break an hundred oaths to reign
one year.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And if it please your grace to give me leave,
I will show your grace the way to save your oath,
And dispossess king Henrie from the crown.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I prithee Dicke let me hear thy devise.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Then thus my Lord. An oath is of no moment
Being not sworn before a lawful magistrate.
Henry is none but doth usurp your right,
And yet your grace stands bound to him by oath.
Then noble father resolve yourself,
And once more claim the crown.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Aye, sayst thou so boy? why then it shall be so.
I am resolved to win the crown, or die.
Edward, thou shalt to Edmund Brooke Lord Cobham,
With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise:
Thou cousin Montague, shalt to Norffolke straight,
And bid the Duke to muster up, his soldiers,
And come to me to Wakefield presently.
And Richard thou to London strait shalt post,
And bid Richard Neuill Earl of Warwike
To leave the city, and with his men of war,
To meet me at Saint Albons ten days hence.
Myself here in Sandall castle will provide
Both men and money to further our attempts.
Now, what news?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: My Lord, the Queen with thirty thousand men,
Accompanied with the Earls of Cumberland,
Northumberland and Westmerland, and others of the
House of Lancaster, are marching towards Wakefield,
To besiege you in your castle here .

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn and sir Hugh Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: In Gods name, let them come. Cousin Montague post you hence: and boys stay you with me.
Sir Iohn and sir Hugh Mortemers mine uncles,
You are welcome to Sandall in an happy hour,
The army of the Queen means to besiege us.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: She shall not need my Lord, we will meet
her in the field.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: What with five thousand soldiers uncle?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Aye father, with five hundred for a need,
A woman is general, what should you fear?

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Indeed, many brave battles have I won
In Normandie, when as the enemy
Hath been ten to one, and why should I now doubt
Of the like success? I am resolved. Come let us go.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Let us march away, I hear their drums.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and then Enter the yong Earle of Rutland and his Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.l: O fly my Lord, let us leave the Castle,
And fly to Wakefield straight.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: O Tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Chaplain away, thy Priesthood saves thy life,
As for the brat of that accursed Duke
Whose father slew my father, he shall die.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.l: O Clifford spare this tender Lord, lest
Heaven revenge it on thy head: O save his life.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Soldiers away and drag him hence perforce:
Away with the villain.
How now, what dead already ? or is it fear that
Makes him close his eyes? I will open them.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: So looks the pent up Lion on the lamb,
And so he walks insulting over his pray,
And so he turns again to rend his limbs in sunder,
O Clifford, kill me with thy sword, and
Not with such a cruel threatening look,
I am too mean a subject for thy wrath,
Be thou revenged on men, and let me live.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: In vain thou speakest poor boy: my father's
Blood hath stopped the passage where thy words should
enter.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Then let my father's blood ope it again? he is a
Man, and Clifford cope with him.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Had I thy brethren here, their lives and thine
Were not revenge sufficient for me.
Or should I dig up thy forefathers graves,
And hang their rotten coffins up in chains,
It could not slake mine ire, nor ease my hart.
The sight of any, of the house of Yorke,
Is as a fury to torment my soul.
Therefore till I root out that cursed line
And leave not one on earth, I will live in hell therefore.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: O let me pray, before I take my death.
To thee I pray: Sweet Clifford pity me.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Aye, such pity as my rapiers point affords.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I never did thee hurt, wherefore wilt thou kill
me?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Thy father hath.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But it was ere I was borne.
Thou hast one son, for his sake pity me,
Lest, in revenge thereof, sith God is just.
He be as miserably slain as I.
O, let me live in prison all my days,
And when I give occasion of offence,
Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No cause? Thy Father slew my father, therefore
Die.
Plantagenet I come Plantagenet,
And this thy son's blood cleaving to my blade,
Shall rust upon my weapon, till thy blood
Congealed with his, do make me wipe off both.

div2.stage: Alarmes, Enter the Duke of Yorke solus.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Ah Yorke, post to thy castle, save thy life,
The goal is lost thou house of Lancaster,
Thrice happy chance is it for thee and thine,
That heaven abridged my days and calls me hence,
But God knows what chance hath betide my sons;
But this I know they have demeaned themselves,
Like men borne to renown by life or death:
Three times this day came Richard to my sight,
And cried courage Father: Victory or death,
And twice so oft came Edward to my view,
With purple Falchion painted to the hilts,
In blood of those whom he had slaughtered.
O hark, I hear the drums? No way to fly:
No way to save my life? And here I stay:
And here my life must end.

div2.stage: Enter the Queene, Clifford, Northumberland, and souldiers.

sp.l: Come bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland,
I dare your quenchless fury to more blood:
This is the butt, and this abides your shot.

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Yield to our mercies proud Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Aye, to such mercy as his ruthful arm
With downright payment lent unto my father,
Now Phaeton hath tumbled from his car,
And made an evening at the noon tide prick.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: My ashes like the Phoenix may bring forth
A bird that will revenge it on you all,
And in that hope I cast mine eyes to heaven,
Scorning whatever you can afflict me with:
Why stay you Lords? what, multitudes and fear?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: So cowards fight when they can fly no longer:
So Doves do peck the Ravens' piercing talents:
So desperate thieves all hopeless of their lives,
Breath out invectives against the officers.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: O Clifford, yet bethink thee once again,
And in thy mind overrun my former time:
And bite thy tongue that slanderest him with cowardice,
Whose very look hath made thee quake ere this.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I will not bandy with thee word for word,
But buckle with thee blows twice two for one.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Hold valiant Clifford for a thousand causes,
I would prolong the traitors life a while.
Wrath makes him death, speak thou Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Hold Clifford do not honour him so much,
To prick thy finger though to wound his hart:
What valour were it when a cur doth grin,
For one to thrust his hand between his teeth,
When he might spurn him with his foot away?
It is wars prise to take all advantages,
And ten to one, is no impeach in wars.
Fight and take him.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, so strives the Woodcock with the gin.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: So doth the cony struggle with the net.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: So triumphs thieves upon their conquered
Booty: So true men yield by robbers overmatched.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: What will your grace have done with him?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Brave warriors Clifford and Northumberland
Come make him stand upon this molehill here,
That aimed at mountains with outstretched arm,
And parted but the shadow with his hand.
Was it you that reveled in our Parliament,
And made a preachment of your high descent?
Where are your mess of sons to back you now?
The wanton Edward, and the lusty George?
Or where is that valiant Crookbackt prodigy?
Dickey your boy, that with his grumbling voice,
Was wont to cheer his Dad in mutinies?
Or amongst the rest where is your darling Rutland?
Look Yorke? I dipped this napkin in the blood,
That valiant Clifford with his rapiers point,
Made issue from the bosom of thy boy.
And if thine eyes can water for his death,
I give thee this to dry thy cheeks withal.
Alas poor Yorke: But that I hate thee much,
I should lament thy miserable state?
I prithee grieve to make me merry Yorke?
Stamp rave and fret, that I may sing and dance.
What: hath thy fiery hart so parched thine entrails,
That not a tear can fall for Rutlands death?
Thou wouldst be feed I see to make me sport.
Yorke cannot speak, unless he wear a crown.
A crown for Yorke? and Lords bow low to him.
So: hold you his hands, whilst I do set it on.
Aye, now looks he like a king?
This is he that took king Henries chair,
And this is he was his adopted air.
But how is it that great Plantagenet,
Is crowned so soon, and broke his holy oath,
As I bethink me you should not be king,
Till our Henry had shook hands with death,
And will you impale your head with Henries glory,
And rob his temples of the Diadem
Now in his life against your holy oath?
O, it is a fault too too unpardonable.
Off with the crown, and with the crown his head,
And whilst we breath, take time to do him dead.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: That is my office for my father's death.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet stay: and let us hear the Orisons he makes.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: She-wolf of France, but worse than Wolves of
France:
Whose tongue more poisoned than the Adder's tooth:
How ill beseeming is it in thy sex,
To triumph like an Amazonian trull
Upon his woes, whom Fortune captivates?
But that thy face is vizard-like, unchanging,
Made impudent by use of evil deeds:
I would assay, proud Queen to make thee blush:
To tell thee of whence thou art, from whom derived,
It were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not
shameless.
Thy father bears the type of king of Naples,
Of both the Sissiles and Ierusalem,
Yet not so wealthy as an English Yeoman.
Hath that poor Monarch taught thee to insult?
It needs not, or it boots thee not proud Queen,
Unless the Adage must be verified:
That beggars mounted, run their horse to death.
It is beauty, that oft makes women proud,
But God he wots thy share thereof is small.
It is government, that makes them most admired,
The contrary doth make thee wondered at.
It is vertue that makes them seem divine,
The want thereof makes thee abominable.
Thou art as opposite to every good,
As the Antipodes are unto us,
Or as the south to the Septentrion.
O Tiger's hart wrapped in a woman's hide?
How couldst thou drain the life blood of the child,
To bid the father wipe his eyes withal,
And yet be seen to bear a woman's face?
Women are mild, pitiful, and flexible,
Thou endurate, stern, rough, remorseless.
Bids thou me rage? why now thou hast thy will
Wouldst have me weep? why so thou hast thy wish.
For raging winds blows up a storm of tears,
And when the rage allays the rain begins.
These tears are my sweet Rutlands obsequies,
And every drop begs vengeance as it falls,
on thee fell Clifford, and the false French woman.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Beshrew me but his passions move me so,
As hardly can I check mine eyes from tears.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: That face of his the hungry Cannibals
Could not have touched, would not have stained with blood
But you are more inhumane, more inexorable,
O ten times more than Tigers of Arcadia.
See ruthless Queen a hapless father's tears.
This cloth thou dipths in blood of my sweet boy,
And lo with tears I wash the blood away.
Keep thou the napkin and go boast of that,
And if thou tell the heavy story well,
Upon my soul the hearers will shed tears,
Aye, even my foes will shed fast falling tears,
And say, alas, it was a piteous deed.
Here, take the crown, and with the crown my curse,
And in thy need such comfort come to thee,
As now I reap at thy two cruel hands.
Hardhearted Clifford, take me from the world,
My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Had he been slaughterman of all my kin,
I could not choose but weep with him to see,
How inly anger gripes his hart.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What weeping ripe, my Lord Northumberland?
Think but upon the wrong he did us all,
And that will quickly dry your melting tears.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: There is for my oath there is for my father's death.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And there is to right our gentle hearted kind.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Open thy gates of mercy gracious God,
My soul flies forth to meet with thee.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Off with his head and set it on Yorke Gates,
So Yorke may overlook the town of Yorke.

div2.stage: Enter Edward and Richard, with drum and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: After this dangerous fight and hapless war,
How doth my noble brother Richard fare?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I cannot joy until I be resolved,
Where our right valiant father is become,
How often did I see him bear himself,
As doth a lion midst a heard of neat,
So fled his enemies our valiant father,
Methinks it is pride enough to be his son.

div2.stage: Three sunnes appeare in the aire.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lo how the morning opes her golden gates,
And takes her farewell of the glorious sun,
Dazzle mine eyes or do I see three suns?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Three glorious suns, not separated by a racking
Cloud, but severed in a pale clear shining sky.
See, see, they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,
As if they vowed some league inviolate:
Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun,
In this the heavens doth figure some event.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I think it cites us brother to the field,
That we the sons of brave Plantagenet,
Already each one shining by his meed,
May join in one and overpeer the world,
As this the earth, and therefore hence forward,
I will bear upon my Target, three fair shining suns.
But what art thou? that lookest so heavily?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: O one that was a woeful looker on,
When as the noble Duke of Yorke was slain.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: O speak no more, for I can hear no more.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Tell on thy tale, for I will hear it all.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: When as the noble Duke was put to flight,
And then pursued by Clifford and the Queen,
And many soldiers mo, who all at once
Let drive at him and forced the Duke to yield:
And then they set him on a molehill there,
And crowned the gracious Duke in high despite,
Who then with tears began to wail his fall.
The ruthless Queen perceiving he did weep,
Gave him a handkercher to wipe his eyes,
Dipped in the blood of sweet young Rutland
By rough Clifford slain: who weeping took it up.
Then through his breast they thrust their bloody swords,
Who like a lamb fell at the butchers feet.
Then on the gates of Yorke they set his head,
And there it doth remain the piteous spectacle
That ever mine eyes beheld.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Sweet Duke of Yorke our prop to lean upon ,
Now thou art gone there is no hope for us:
Now my soul's palace is become a prison.
O would she break from compass of my breast,
For never shall I have more joy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I cannot weep, for all my breasts moisture
Scarce serves to quench my furnace burning hart:
I cannot joy till this white rose be dyed,
Even in the hart blood of the house of Lancaster.
Richard I bare thy name, and I will revenge thy death,
Or die myself in seeking of revenge.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: His name that valiant Duke hath left with thee,
His chair and Dukedom that remains for me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay, if thou be that princely Eagles bird,
Show thy descent by gazing against the sun.
For chair, and dukedom, Throne and kingdom say:
For either that is thine, or else thou wert not his?

div2.stage: Enter the Earle of Warwike, Montague, with drum, ancient, and souldiers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How now fair Lords: what fare? what
news abroad?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Ah Warwike? should we report the baleful
News, and at each word's deliverance stab poniards
In our flesh till all were told, the words would add
More anguish than the wounds.
Ah valiant Lord the Duke of Yorke is slain.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Ah Warwike Warwike, that Plantagenet,
Which held thee dear: Aye, even as his soul's redemption,
Is by the stern Lord. Clifford, done to death.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ten days ago I drowned those news in tears.
And now to add more measure to your woes,
I come to tell you things since then befallen.
After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought,
Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp,
Tidings as shuffle as the post could run,
Was brought me of your loss, and his departure.
I then in London keeper of the King,
Mustered my soldiers, gathered flocks of friends,
And very well appointed as I thought,
Marched to saint Albons to intercept the Queen,
Bearing the King in my behalf along,
For by my scouts I was advertised,
That she was coming, with a full intent
To dash your late decree in parliament,
Touching king Henries heirs and your succession.
Short tale to make, we at Saint Albons met,
Our battles joined, and both sides fiercely fought,
But whether it was the coldness of the king,
He looked full gently on his warlike Queen,
That robbed my soldiers of their heated spleen.
Or whether it was report of his success,
Or more than common fear of Cliffords rigour,
Who thunders to his captains blood and death,
I cannot tell. But to conclude with truth,
Their weapons like to lightnings went and came.
Our soldiers like the night Owl's lazy flight,
Or like an idle thresher with a flail,
Fell gently down as if they smote their friends.
I cheered them up with justice of the cause,
With promise of hie pay and great rewards,
But all in vain, they had no hearts to fight,
Nor we in them no hope to win the day,
So that We fled. The king unto the Queen,
Lord George your brother, Norffolke, and myself,
In haste, post haste, are come to join with you,
For in the marches here we heard you were,
Making another head to fight again.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thanks gentle Warwike.
How far hence is the Duke with his power?
And when came George from Burgundie to England?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Some five miles off the Duke is with his power,
But as for your brother he was lately sent
From your kind Aunt, Duchess of Burgundie,
With aid of soldiers against this needful war.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It was odds belike, when valiant Warwike fled.
Oft have I heard thy praises in pursuit,
But never till now thy scandal of retire.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Nor now my scandal Richard dost thou hear,
For thou shalt know that this right hand of mine,
Can pluck the Diadem from faint Henries head,
And wring the awful sceptre from his fist:
Were he as famous and as bold in war,
As he is famed for mildness, peace and prayer.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I know it well Lord Warwike blame me not,
It was love I bare thy glories made me speak.
But in this troublous time, whats to be done?
Shall we go throw away our coats of steel,
And clad our bodies in black mourning gowns,
Numbering our Ave-marias with our beads?
Or shall we on the helmets of our foes,
Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?
If for the last say I, and to it Lords.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why therefore Warwike came to find you out,
And therefore comes my brother Montague.
Attend me Lords, the proud insulting Queen,
With Clifford and the haught Northumberland,
And of their feather many mo proud birds,
Have wrought the easy melting king like wax.
He sware consent to your succession,
His oath enrolled in the Parliament.
But now to London all the crew are gone,
To frustrate his oath or what besides
May make against the house of Lancaster.
Their power I guess them fifty thousand strong.
Now if the help of Norffolke, and myself,
Can but amount to 48. thousand,
With all the friends that thou brave earl of March,
Among the loving Welshmen canst procure,
Why via, To London will we march amain,
And once again bestride our foaming steeds,
And once again cry charge upon the foe,
But never once again turn back and fly.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Aye, now methinks I hear great Warwike speak:
Never may he live to see a sunshine day,
That cries retire, when Warwike bids him stay.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lord Warwike, on thy shoulder will I lean,
And when thou faints, must Edward fall:
Which peril heaven forfend.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of Yorke,
The next degree, is Englands royal king:
And king of England shalt thou be proclaimed,
In every borough as we pass along:
And he that casts not up his cap for joy,
Shall for the offence make forfeit of his head.
King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague,
Stay we no longer dreaming of renown,
But forward to effect these resolutions.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: The Duke of Norffolke sends you word by me,
The Queen is coming with a puissant power,
And craves your company for speedy counsel.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why then it sorts brave Lords. Let us march away.

div2.stage: Enter the King and Queene, Prince Edward and the Northerne Earles, with drum and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord to this brave town of York,
Yonder is the head of that ambitious enemy,
That sought to be impaled with your crown.
Doth not the object please your eye my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Even as the rocks please them that fear their
wrack.
Withhold revenge dear God, it is not my fault,
Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, this too much lenity,
And harmful pity must be laid aside,
To whom do Lions cast their gentle looks?
Not to the beast that would usurp his den.
Whose hand is that the savage Bear doth lick?
Not his that spoils his young before his face.
Whose scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting?
Not he that sets his foot upon her back.
The smallest worm will turn being trodden on,
And Doves will peck, in rescue of their brood.
Ambitious Yorke did level at thy Crown,
Thou smiling, while he knit his angry brows.
He but a Duke, would have his son a king,
And raise his issue like a loving sire.
Thou being a king blessed with a goodly son,
Didst give consent to disinherit him,
Which argued thee a most unnatural father.
Unreasonable creatures feed their young,
And though man's face be fearful to their eyes,
Yet in protection of their tender ones,
Who hath not seen them even with those same wings
Which they have sometime used in fearful flight,
Make war with him, that climes unto their nest,
Offering their own lives in their young's defence?
For shame my Lord, make them your president,
Were it not pity that this goodly boy,
Should lose his birthright through his father's fault?
And long hereafter say unto his child,
What my great grandfather and grandsire got,
My careless father fondly gave away?
Look on the boy and let his manly face,
Which promiseth successful fortune to us all,
Steel thy melting thoughts,
To keep thine own, and leave thine own with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Full well hath Clifford played the Orator,
Inferring arguments of mighty force.
But tell me, didst thou never yet hear tell.
That things evil got had ever bad success,
And happy ever was it for that son,
Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?
I leave my son my virtuous deeds behind,
And would my father had left me no more,
For all the rest is held at such a rate,
As asks a thousand times more care to keep,
Than may the present profit countervail.
Ah cousin Yorke, would thy best friends did know,
How it doth grieve me that thy head stands there.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: My Lord this harmful pity makes your followers faint.
You promised knighthood to your princely son.
Unsheathe your sword and straight do dub him knight.
Kneel down Edward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Edward Plantagenet arise a knight,
And learn this lesson boy, draw thy thy sword in right

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: My gracious father by your kingly leave,
I will draw it as apparent to the crown,
And in that quarrel use it to the death.

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: Why that is spoken like a toward prince.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Royal commanders be in readiness,
For with a band of fifty thousand men,
Comes Warwike backing of the Duke of Yorke.
And in the towns whereas they pass along,
Proclaims him king, and many flies to him,
Prepare your battles, for they be at hand.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I would your highness would depart the field,
The Queen hath best success when you are absent.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Do good my Lord, and leave us to our fortunes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why that is my fortune, therefore I will stay still.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Be it with resolution then to fight.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Good father cheer these noble Lords,
Unsheathe your sword, sweet father cry Saint George.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Pitch we our battle here , for hence we will not
move.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Now perjured Henrie wilt thou yield thy crown,
And kneel for mercy at thy sovereign's feet?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Go rate thy minions proud insulting boy,
Becomes it thee to be thus malapert,
Before thy king and lawful sovereign?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I am his king and he should bend his knee,
I was adopted heir by his consent.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Since when he hath broke his oath.
For as we hear you that are king
Though he do wear the Crown,
Have caused him by new act of Parliament
To blot our brother out, and put his own son in.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: And reason George. Who should succeed the father but the son?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Are you their butcher?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Aye Crookbacke, here I stand to answer thee, or any
of your sort.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It was you that killed young Rutland, was it not?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Yes, and old Yorke too, and yet not satisfied.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: For Gods sake Lords give signal to the fight.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What sayst thou Henry? wilt thou yield thy
crown?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What, long-tongued Warwick dare you speak?
When you and I met at saint Albones last,
Your legs did better service than your hands.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye, then it was my turn to flee, but now it is thine.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It was not your valour Clifford, that drove me
thence.

sp.speaker: Northum.
sp.l: No nor your manhood Warwike, that could
make you stay.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Northumberland, Northumberland, we hold
Thee reverently. Break off the parley, for scarce
I can refrain the execution of my big swollen
Hart, against that Clifford there, that
Cruel child-killer.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Why I killed thy father, callest thou him a child?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Aye like a villain, and a treacherous coward,
As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland.
But ere sun set I will make thee curse the deed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have done with words great Lords, and
Hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I prithee give no limits to my tongue,
I am king and privilege to speak.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: My Lord the wound that bred this meeting here
Cannot be cured with words, therefore be still.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Then executioner unsheathe thy sword,
By him that made us all I am resolved,
That Cliffords manhood hangs upon his tongue.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What sayst thou Henry, shall I have my right
or no?
A thousand men have broke their fast today,
That never shall dine, unless thou yield the crown.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: If thou deny their bloods be on thy head,
For Yorke in justice puts his armour on.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: If all be right that Warwike says is right,
There is no wrong but all things must be right.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Whosoever got thee, there thy mother stands,
For well I wot thou hast thy mothers tongue.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam,
But like a soul misshapen stigmatic
Marked by the destinies to be avoided,
As venom Toads, or Lizards fainting looks.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Iron of Naples, hid with English gilt,
Thy father bears the title of a king,
As if a channel should be called the Sea;
Shames thou not, knowing from whence thou art derived, to parley thus with Englands lawful heirs?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns,
To make that shameless callet know herself,
Thy husband's father reveled in the hart of France,
And tamed the French, and made the Dolphin stoop:
And had he matched according to his state,
He might have kept that glory till this day.
But when he took a beggar to his bed,
And gracest thy poor sire with his bridal day,
Then that sun-shine bred a shower for him
Which washed his father's fortunes out of France,
And heaped seditions on his crown at home.
For what hath moved these tumults but thy pride?
Hadst thou been meek, our title yet had slept?
And we in pity of the gentle king,
Had slipped our claim until another age.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: But when we saw our summer brought the
gain,
And that the harvest brought us no increase,
We set the axe to thy usurping root,
And though the edge have something hit ourselves,
Yet know thou we will never cease to strike,
Till we have hewn thee down,
Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And in this resolution, I defy thee,
Not willing any, longer conference,
Since thou deniest the gentle king to speak.
Sound trumpets, let our bloody colours wave,
And either victory or else a grave.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Stay Edward stay.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Hence wrangling woman, I will no longer stay,
Thy words will cost ten thousand lives today.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sore spent with toil as runners with the race,
I lay me down a little while to breath,
For strokes received, and many blows repaid,
Hath robbed my strong knit sinews of their strength,
And force perforce needs must I rest myself.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Smile gentle heavens or strike ungentle death,
That we may die unless we gain the day:
What fatal star malignant frowns from heaven
Upon the harmless line of Yorkes true house?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Come brother, come, let us to the field again,
For yet there is hope enough, to win the day:
Then let us back to cheer our fainting Troupes,
Lest they retire now we have left the field.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How now my lords: what hap, what hope of good?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Ah Warwike, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?
Thy noble father in the thickest throngs,
Cried still for Warwike his thrice valiant son,
Until with thousand swords he was beset,
And many wounds made in his aged breast,
And as he tottering sate upon his steed,
He waft his hand to me and cried aloud.
Richard, commend me to my valiant son,
And still he cried Warwike revenge my death,
And with those words he tumbled off his horse,
And so the noble Salsbury gave up the ghost.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then let the earth be drunken with his blood,
I will kill my horse because I will not fly:
And here to God of heaven I make a vow,
Never to pass from forth this bloody field
Till I am full revenged for his death.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lord Warwike, I do bend my knees with thine,
And in that vow now join my soul to thee,
Thou setter up and puller down of kings,
vouchsafe a gentle victory to us,
Or let us die before we loose the day:

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Then let us haste to cheer the soldiers' hearts,
And call them pillars that will stand to us,
And highly promise to remunerate
Their trusty service, in these dangerous wars.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Come, come away, and stand not to debate,
For yet is hope of fortune good enough.
Brothers, give me your hands, and let us part
And take our leaves until we meet again,
Wherever it be in heaven or in earth.
Now I that never wept, now melt in woe,
To see these dire mishaps continue so.
Warwike farewell.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Away away, once more sweet Lords farewell.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and then enter Richard at one dore and Clifford at the other.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: A Clifford a Clifford.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: A Richard a Richard.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Now Clifford, for Yorke and young Rutlands death,
This thirsty sword that longs to drink thy blood,
Shall lop thy limbs, and slice thy cursed hart,
For to revenge the murders thou hast made.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Now Richard, I am with thee here alone,
This is the hand that stabbed thy father Yorke,
And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland,
And here is the heart that triumphs in their deaths,
And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother,
To execute the like upon thyself,
And so have at thee.

div2.stage: Alarmes. They fight, and then enters Warwike and rescues Richard, and then exeunt omnes.
Alarme still, and then enter Henry Solus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: O gracious God of heaven look down on us,
And set some ends to these incessant griefs,
How like a mastless ship upon the seas,
This woeful battle doth continue still,
Now leaning this way, now to that side drive,
And none doth know to whom the day will fall.
O would my death might stay these civil jars!
Would I had never reigned, nor never been king,
Margret and Clifford, chide me from the field,
Swearing they had best success when I was thence.
Would God that I were dead so all were well,
Or would my crown suffice, I were content
To yield it them and live a private life.

div2.stage: Enter a souldier with a dead man in his armes.

sp.speaker: Sould
sp.l: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody,
This man that I have slain in fight today,
May be possessed of some store of crowns,
And I will search to find them if I can,
But stay. Methinks it is my father's face,
O I it is he whom I have slain in fight,
From London was I pressed out by the king,
My father he came on the part of Yorke,
And in this conflict I have slain my father:
O pardon God, I knew not what I did,
And pardon father, for I knew thee not.

div2.stage: Enter another souldier with a dead man.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Lie there thou that foughtest with me so stoutly,
Now let me see what store of gold thou hast,
But stay, methinks this is no famous face:
O no it is my son that I have slain in fight,
O monstrous times begetting such events,
How cruel bloody, and ironious,
This deadly quarrel daily doth beget,
Poor boy thy father gave thee life too late,
And hath bereaved thee of thy life too soon.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Woe above woe, grief more than common grief,
Whilst Lions war and battle for their dens,
Poor lambs do feel the rigour of their wraths:
The red rose and the white are on his face,
The fatal colours of our striving houses,
Wither one rose, and let the other flourish,
For if you strive, ten thousand lives must perish.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: How will my mother for my father's death,
Take on with me and never be satisfied?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: How will my wife for slaughter of my son,
Take on with me and never be satisfied?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How will the people now misdeem their king.
O would my death their minds could satisfy.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: Was ever son so rude his father's blood to spill?

sp.speaker: 2, Soul.
sp.l: Was ever father so unnatural his son to kill?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was ever king thus grieved and vexed still?

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: I will bear thee hence from this accursed place,
For woe is me to see my father's face.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: I will bear thee hence and let them fight that will,
For I have murdered where I should not kill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Weep wretched man, I will lay thee tear for tear,
Here sits a king as woe begone as thee.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Away my Lord to Barwicke presently,
The day is lost, our friends are murdered,
No hope is left for us, therefore away.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: O father fly, our men have left the field,
Take horse sweet father, let us save ourselves.

sp.speaker: Exet.
sp.l: Away my Lord for vengeance comes along with him:
Nay stand not to expostulate make haste,
Or else come after, I will away before.

sp.speaker: K Hen.
sp.l: Nay stay good Exeter, for I will along with thee.

div2.stage: Enter Clifford wounded, with an arrow in his necke.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Here burns my candle out,
That whilst it lasted gave king Henry light.
Ah Lancaster, I fear thine overthrow,
More than my bodies parting from my soul.
My love and fear glued many friends to thee,
And now I die, that tough commixture melts.
Impairing Henry strengthened misproud Yorke,
The common people swarm like summer flies,
And whither flies the Gnats but to the sun?
And who shines now but Henries enemy?
O Phoebus hadst thou never given consent,
That Phaeton should check thy fiery steeds,
Thy burning car had never scorched the earth.
And Henry hadst thou lived as kings should do,
And as thy father and his father did,
Giving no foot unto the house of Yorke,
I and ten thousand in this woeful land,
Had left no mourning Widows for our deaths,
And thou this day hadst kept thy throne in peace.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
And what makes robbers bold but lenity?
Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds,
No way to fly, no strength to hold our flight,
The foe is merciless and will not pity me,
And at their hands I have deserved no pity.
The air is got into my bleeding wounds,
And much effuse of blood doth make me faint,
Come Yorke and Richard, Warwike and the rest,
I stabbed your fathers, now come split my breast.

div2.stage: Enter Edward, Richard and Warwike, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thus far our fortunes keeps an upward
Course, and we are graced with wreathes of victory.
Some troops pursue the bloody minded Queen,
That now towards Barwike doth post amain,
But think you that Clifford is fled away with them?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No, it is impossible he should escape,
For though before his face I speak the words,
Your brother Richard marked him for the grave.
And wheresoever he be I warrant him dead.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Hark, what soul is this that takes his heavy leave?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: A deadly groan, like life and deaths departure.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: See who it is, and now the battle is ended,
Friend or foe, let him be friendly used.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Reverse that doom of mercy, for it is Clifford.
Who killed our tender brother Rutland,
And stabbed our princely father Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: From off the gates of Yorke fetch down the
Head, Your father's head which Clifford placed there,
Instead of that, let his supply the room.
Measure for measure must be answered.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to
our house,
That nothing sung to us but blood and death,
Now his evil boding tongue no more shall speak.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I think his understanding is bereft.
Say Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?
Dark cloudy death over-shades his beams of life,
And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O would he did, and so perhaps he doth,
And it is his policy that in the time of death,
He might avoid such bitter storms as he
In his hour of death did give unto our father.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Richard if thou thinkest so, vex him with eager words.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Clifford devise excuses for thy fault.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Whilst we devise fell tortures for thy fault.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Thou pitiedest Yorke, and I am son to Yorke.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thou pitiedest Rutland, and I will pity thee.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Where is captain Margaret to fence you
now?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: They mock thee Clifford, swear as thou wast
wont.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What not an oath? Nay, then I know he is dead,
It is hard, when Clifford cannot ford his friend an oath.
By this I know he is dead, and by my soul,
Would this right hand buy but an hour's life,
That I in all contempt might rail at him.
I would cut it off and with the issuing blood,
Stifle the villain whose unstaunched thirst,
Yorke and young Rutland could not satisfy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye, but he is dead, off with the traitors head,
And rear it in the place your fathers stands.
And now to London with triumphant march,
There to be crowned Englands lawful king.
From thence shall Warwike cross the seas to France,
And ask the lady Bona for thy Queen,
So shalt thou sinew both these lands together,
And having France thy friend thou needst not dread,
The scattered foe that hopes to rise again.
And though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,
Yet look to have them busy to offend thine ears.
First I will see the coronation done,
And afterward I will cross the seas to France,
To effect this marriage if it please my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Even as thou wilt good Warwike let it be.
But first before we go, George kneel down.
We here create thee Duke of Clarence, and girt thee with
the sword.
Our younger brother Richard Duke of Glocester.
Warwike as myself shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloster,
For Glosters Dukedom is too ominous.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Tush that is a childish observation.
Richard be Duke of Gloster. Now to London.
To see these honours in possession.

div2.stage: Enter two keepers with bow and arrowes.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Come, let us take our stands upon this hill,
And by and by the dear will come this way.
But stay, here comes a man, let us listen him a while.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: From Scotland am I stolen even of pure love,
And thus disguised to greet my native land.
No, Henrie no. It is no land of thine,
No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,
No humble suitors sues to thee for right,
For how canst thou help them and not thyself?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Aye marry sir, here is a dear, his skin is a
Keepers fee. Sirrah stand close, for as I think,
This is the king, king Edward hath deposed.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My Queen and son poor souls are gone to
France, and as I hear the great commanding Warwike,
To entreat a marriage with the lady Bona,
If this be true; poor Queen and son,
Your labour is but spent in vain,
For Lewis is a prince soon won with words,
And Warwike is a subtle Orator.
He laughs and says, his Edward is installed,
She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed,
He on his right hand asking a wife for Edward,
She on his left side craving aid for Henry.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: What art thou that talks of kings and queens?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: More than I seem, for less I should not be.
A man at least, and more I cannot be,
And men may talk of kings, and why not I?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Aye but thou talkest as if thou wert a king thyself.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why so I am in mind though not in show.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: And if thou be a king where is thy crown?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My crown is in my hart, not on my head.
My crown is called content, a crown that
Kings do seldom times enjoy.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: And if thou be a king crowned with content,
Your crown content and you, must be content
To go with us unto the officer, for as we think
You are our quondam king, King Edward hath deposed,
And therefore we charge you in Gods name and the kings
To go along with us unto the officers.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Gods name be fulfilled, your kings name be
Obeyed, and be you kings, command and I will obey.

div2.stage:
Enter king Edward, Clarence, and Gloster, Montague,
Hastings, and the Lady Gray.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Brothers of Clarence, and of Glocester,
This ladies husband here sir Richard Gray,
At the battle of saint Alkones did lose his life,
His lands then were seized on by the conqueror.
Her suit is now to repossess those lands,
And sith in quarrel of the house of Yorke,
The noble gentleman did lose his life,
In honour we cannot deny her suit.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Your highness shall do well to grant it then.

sp.speaker: K Edw
sp.l: Aye, so I will, but yet I will make a pause.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye, is the wind in that door?

sp.speaker: Clarence,
sp.l: I see the Lady hath something to grant,
Before the king will grant her humble suit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He knows the game, how well he keeps the wind.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Widow come some other time to know our mind.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: May it please your grace I cannot brooke delays,
I beseech your highness to dispatch me now.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: Lords give us leave, we mean to try this widow's wit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Aye, good leave have you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: For you will have leave till youth take leave,
And leave you to your crouch.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: Come hither widow, how many children hast
thou?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I think he means to beg a child on her.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay whip me then, he will rather give her two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Three my most gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You shall have four and you will be ruled by him.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: Were it not pity they should loose their fathers'
lands?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Be pitiful then dread Lord. and grant it them.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: I will tell thee how these lands are to be got.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So shall you bind me to your highness' service.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: What service wilt thou do me if I grant it them?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Even what your highness shall command.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay then widow I will warrant you all your
Husband's lands, if you grant to do what he
Commands. Fight close or in good faith
You catch a clap.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay I fear her not unless she fall.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Marry godsforbot man, for he will take vantage
then.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why stops my Lord, shall I not know my task?

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: An easy task, it is but to love a king.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That is soon performed, because I am a subject.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: Why then thy husband's lands I freely give
thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The match is made, she seals it with a curtsy.

sp.speaker: K Ed
sp.l: Stay widow stay, what love dost thou think
I sue so much to get?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My humble service, such as subjects owes
and the laws commands.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: No by my troth, I meant no such love,
But to tell thee the troth, I aim to lie with thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To tell you plain my Lord, I had rather lie
in prison.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Why then thou canst not get thy husband's
lands.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then mine honesty shall be my dower,
For by that loss I will not purchase them.

sp.speaker: K Ed.
sp.l: Herein thou wrongest thy children mightily.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Herein your highness wrongs both them and
Me, but mighty Lord this merry inclination
Agrees not with the sadness of my suit.
Please it your highness to dismiss me either with I or no.

sp.speaker: K Ed
sp.l: Aye, if thou say aye to my request,
No, if thou say no to my demand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then no my Lord, my suit is at an end.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The widow likes him not, she bends the brow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why he is the bluntest wooer in christendom.

sp.speaker: K Ed
sp.l: Her looks are all replete with majesty,
One way or other she is for a king,
And she shall be my love or else my Queen.
Say that king Edward took thee for his Queen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is better said than done, my gracious Lord,
I am a subject fit to jest withal,
But far unfit to be a Sovereign.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Sweet widow, by my state I swear, I speak
No more than what my hart intends,
And that is to enjoy thee for my love.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And that is more than I will yield unto,
I know I am too bad to be your Queen,
And yet too good to be your Concubine.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: You cavil widow, I did mean my Queen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your grace would be loath my sons should call
you father.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: No more than when my daughters call thee
Mother. Thou art a widow and thou hast some children,
And by Gods mother I being but a bachelor
Have other some. Why it is a happy thing
To be the father of many children.
Argue no more, for thou shalt be my Queen.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The ghostly father now hath done his shrift.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: When he was made a shriver it was for shift.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Brothers, you muse what talk the widow
And I have had, you would think it strange
If I should marry her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Marry her my Lord, to whom?

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Why Clarence to myself.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why that is a day longer than a wonder lasts.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And so much more are the wonders in extremes.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Well, jest on brothers, I can tell you, her
Suit is granted for her husband's lands.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: If it please your grace, Henry your foe is
Taken, and brought as prisoner to your palace gates.

sp.speaker: K Edw.
sp.l: Away with him and send him to the Tower,
And let us go question with the man about
His apprehension. Lords along, and use this
Lady honourably.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Aye, Edward will use women honourably,
Would he were wasted marrow, bones and all,
That from his loins no issue might succeed
To hinder me from the golden time I look for,
For I am not yet looked on in the world.
First is there Edward, Clarence, and Henry
And his son, and all they looked-for issue
Of their loins ere I can plant myself,
A cold premeditation for my purpose,
What other pleasure is there in the world beside?
I will go clad my body in gay ornaments,
And lull myself within a ladies lap,
And witch sweet Ladies with my words and looks.
O monstrous man, to harbour such a thought!
Why love did scorn me in my mothers womb.
And for I should not deal in her affairs,
She did corrupt frail nature in the flesh,
And placed an envious mountain on my back,
Where sits deformity to mock my body,
To dry mine arm up like a withered shrimp.
To make my legs of an unequal size,
And am I then a man to be beloved?
Easier for me to compass twenty crowns.
Tut I can smile, and murder when I smile,
I cry content, to that that grieves me most.
I can add colours to the Chameleon,
And for a need change shapes with Protheus,
And set the aspiring Catalin to school.
Can I do this, and cannot get the crown?
Tush were it ten times higher, I will pull it down.

div2.stage:
Enter king Lewis and the ladie Bona, and Queene
Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford
> and others.

sp.speaker: Lewes.
sp.l: Welcome Queen Margaret to the Court of
France,
It fits not Lewis to sit while thou dost stand,
Sit by my side, and here I vow to thee,
Thou shalt have aid to repossess thy right,
And beat proud Edward from his usurped seat.
And place king Henry in his former rule.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I humbly thank your royal majesty.
And pray the God of heaven to bless thy state,
Great king of France, that thus regards our wrongs.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How now, who is this?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Our Earl of Warwike Edwardes chiefest friend.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Welcome brave Warwike, what brings thee to
France?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: From worthy Edward king of England,
My Lord and Sovereign and thy vowed friend,
I come in kindness and unfeigned love,
First to do greetings to thy royal person,
And then to crave a league of amity,
And lastly to confirm that amity
With nuptial knot if thou vouchsafe to grant
That virtuous lady Bona thy fair sister,
To Englands king in lawful marriage.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And if this go forward all our hope is done.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And gracious Madam, in our kings behalf,
I am commanded with your love and favour,
Humbly to kiss your hand and with my tongue,
To tell the passions of my sovereign's hart,
Where same late entering at his heedful ears,
Hath placed thy glorious image and thy virtues.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: King Lewes and Lady Bona hear me speak,
Before you answer Warwike or his words,
For he it is hath done us all these wrongs.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Injurious Margaret.

sp.speaker: Prince Ed.
sp.l: And why not Queen?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Because thy father Henry did usurp,
And thou no more art Prince than she is Queen.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Then Warwike disannuls great Iohn of Gaunt,
That did subdue the greatest part of Spaine,
And after Iohn of Gaunt wise Henry the fourth,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the world.
And after this wise prince Henry the fifth,
Who with his prowess conquered all France,
From these our Henries lineally descent.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oxford, how haps that in this smooth discourse
You told not how Henry the sixt had lost
All that Henry the fifth had gotten.
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that,
But for the rest you tell a pedigree
Of threescore and two years a silly time,
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Why Warwike, canst thou deny thy king,
Whom thou obeyedest thirty and eight years,
And bewray thy treasons with a blush?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Can Oxford that did ever fence the right,
Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?
For shame leave Henry and call Edward king.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Call him my king by whom mine elder
Brother the Lord Aubray Vere was done to death,
And more than so, my father even in the
Downfall of his mellowed years,
When age did call him to the door of death?
No Warwike no, whilst life upholds this arm,
This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And I the house of Yorke.

sp.speaker: K Lewes.
sp.l: Queen Margaret, prince Edward and
Oxford, vouchsafe to forbear a while,
Till I do talk a word with Warwike.
Now Warwike even upon thy honour tell me true;
Is Edward lawful king or no?
For I were loath to link with him, that is not lawful heir.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thereon I pawn mine honour and my credit.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What is he gracious in the peoples eyes?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The more, that Henry is unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What is his love to our sister Bona?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Such it seems
As may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have often heard him say and swear,
That this his love was an eternal plant,
The root whereof was fixed in virtues ground,
The leaves and fruit maintained with beauties sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,
Unless the lady Bona quite his pain.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then sister let us hear your firm resolve.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.l: Your grant or your denial shall be mine,
But ere this day I must confess, when I
Have heard your kings deserts recounted,
Mine ears have tempted judgment to desire.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then draw near Queen Margaret and be a
Witness, that Bona shall be wife to the English king.

sp.speaker: Prince Edw.
sp.l: To Edward but not the English king.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease,
Where having nothing nothing can he lose,
And as for you yourself our quondam Queen,
You have a father able to maintain your state,
And better it were to trouble him than France.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here comes some post Warwike to thee or us.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: My Lord ambassador this letter is for you,
Sent from your brother Marquis Montague.
This from our king unto your Majesty.
And these to you Madam, from whom I know not.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: I like it well that our fair Queen and mistress,
Smiles at her news when Warwike frets as his.

sp.speaker: P. Ed.
sp.l: And mark how Lewes stamps as he were nettled.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Now Margaret and Warwike, what are your news?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Mine such as fills my hart full of joy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mine full of sorrow and heart's discontent.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What hath your king married the Lady Gray,
And now to excuse himself sends us a post of papers?
How dares he presume to use us thus?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This proveth Edwards love, and Warwiks honesty.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: King Lewis, I here protest in sight of heaven,
And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss,
That I am clear from this misdeed of Edwards.
No more my king, for he dishonours me,
And most himself, if he could see his shame.
Did I forget that by the house of Yorke.
My father came untimely to his death?
Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?
Did I impale him with the regal Crown,
And thrust king Henry from his native home,
And most ungrateful doth he use me thus?
My gracious Queen pardon what is past,
And henceforth I am thy true servitor,
I will revenge the wrongs done to lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his former state.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes Warwike I do quite forget thy former
Faults, if now thou wilt become king Henries friend.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: So much his friend, aye his unfeigned friend,
That if king Lewes vouchsafe to furnish us
With some few bands of chosen soldiers,
I will undertake to land them on our coast,
And force the Tyrant from his seat by war,
It is not his new made bride shall succour him.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Then at the last I firmly am resolved,
You shall have aid: and English messenger return
In post, and tell false Edward thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over Maskers
To revel it with him and his new bride.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.l: Tell him in hope he will be a Widower shortly,
I will wear the willow garland for his sake.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tell him my mourning weeds be laid aside,
And I am ready to put armour on.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I will uncrown him ere it be long.
There is thy reward, begone.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But now tell me Warwike, what assurance
I shall have of thy true loyalty?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This shall assure my constant loyalty,
If that our Queen and this young prince agree,
I will join mine eldest daughter and my joy
To him forthwith in holy wedlock's bands.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: With all my hart, that match I like full well,
Love her son Edward, she is fair and young,
And give thy hand to Warwike for thy love.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: It is enough, and now we will prepare,
To levy soldiers for to go with you.
And you Lord Bourbon our high Admiral,
Shall waft them safely to the English coast,
And chase proud Edward from his slumbering trance,
For mocking marriage with the name of France.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I came from Edward as Ambassador
But I return his sworn and mortal foe:
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,
But dreadful war shall answer his demand.
Had he none else to make a stale but me?
Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.
I was the chief that raised him to the crown,
And I will be chief to bring him down again,
Not that I pity Henries misery,
But seek revenge on Edwards mockery.

div2.stage:
Enter king Edward, the Queene and Clarence, and
Gloster, and Montague and Hastings, and
Penbrooke, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Brothers of Clarence and of Glocester,
What think you of our marriage with the lady Gray?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord, we think as Warwike and Lewes
That are so slack in judgment, that they will take
No offence at this sudden marriage.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Suppose they do, they are but Lewes and
Warwike, and I am your king and Warwikes,
And will be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And shall, because our king but yet such
Sudden marriages seldom proveth well.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yea brother Richard are you against us too?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Not I my Lord, no, God forfend that I should
Once gainsay your highness' pleasure,
Aye, and it were a pity to sunder them that yoke so well together.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Setting your scorns and your dislikes aside,
Show me some reasons why the Lady Gray,
May not be my love and Englands Queen?
Speak freely Clarence, Gloster,
Montague and Hastings.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My Lord then this is my opinion,
That Warwike being dishonoured in his embassage,
Doth seek revenge to quite his injuries.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And Lewes in regard of his sisters wrongs,
Doth join with Warwike to supplant your state.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Suppose that Lewis and Warwike be appeased,
By such means as I can best devise.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: But yet to have joined with France in this
Alliance, would more have strengthened this our
Common wealth, against foreign storms,
Than any home bred marriage.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Let England be true within itself,
We need not France not any alliance with them.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: For this one speech the Lord Hastings well deserves,
To have the daughter and heir of the Lord Hungerford.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And what then? It was our will it should be so?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Aye, and for such a thing too the Lord Scales
Did well deserve at your hands, to have the
Daughter of the Lord Bonfield, and left your
Brothers to go seek elsewhere, but in
Your madness, you bury your brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Alas poor Clarence, is it for a wife,
That thou art malcontent,
Why man be of good cheer, I will provide thee one.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay you played the broker so ill for yourself,
That you shall give me leave to make my
Choice as I think good, and to that intent,
I shortly mean to leave you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Leave me or tarry I am full resolved.
Edward will not be tied to his brothers wills.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My Lords do me but right and you must
Confess, before it pleased his highness to advance
My state to title of a Queen,
That I was not ignoble in my birth.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Forbear my love to fawn upon their frowns,
For thee they must obey, nay shall obey,
And if they look for favour at my hands.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: My Lord, here is the messenger returned from
France.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now sirrah, What letters or what news?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: No letters my Lord, and such news as without
your highness' special pardon I dare not relate.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: We pardon thee, and as near as thou canst
Tell me, What said Lewis to our letters?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: At my departure these were his very words.
Go tell false Edward thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over Maskers,
To revel it with him and his new bride.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Is Lewis so brave, belike he thinks me Henry.
But what said Lady Bona to these wrongs?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l:
Tell him quoth she, in hope he will prove a widower
shortly, I will wear the willow garland for his sake.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: She had the wrong, indeed she could say
Little less. But what said Henries Queen, for as
I hear, she was then in place?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Tell him quoth she my mourning weeds be
Done, and I am ready to put armour on.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Then belike she means to play the Amazon.
But what said Warwike to these injuries?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: He more incensed than the rest my Lord,
Tell him quoth he, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I will uncrown him ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ha, Durst the traitor breath out such proud words?
But I will arm me to prevent the worst.
But what is Warwike friends with Margaret?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord, they are so linked in friendship,
That young Prince Edward marries Warwikes daughter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The elder, belike Clarence shall have the
Younger. All you that love me and Warwike
Follow me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Clarence and Summerset fled to Warwike.
What say you brother Richard, will you stand to us?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I my Lord, in despite of all that shall
Withstand you For why hath Nature
Made me halt downright, but that I
Should be valiant and stand to it, for if
I would, I cannot run away.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Penbrooke, go raise an army presently,
Pitch up my tent, for in the field this night
I mean to rest, and on the morrow morn,
I will march to meet proud Warwike ere he land
Those straggling troops which he hath got in France.
But ere I go Montague and Hastings,
You of all the rest are nearest allied
In blood to Warwike, therefore tell me, if
You favour him more than me or not:
Speak truly, for I had rather have you open
Enemies, than hollow friends.

sp.speaker: Monta.
sp.l: So God help Montague as he proves true.
