sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And Hastings as he favours Edwards cause.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: It shall suffice, come then let us march away.

div2.stage: Enter Warwike and Oxford, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Trust me my Lords all hitherto goes well,
The common people by numbers swarm to us,
But see where Sommerset and Clarence comes,
Speak suddenly my Lords, are we all friends?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fear not that my Lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then gentle Clarence welcome unto Warwike.
And welcome Summerset, I hold it cowardice,
To rest mistrustful where a noble hart,
Hath pawned an open hand in sign of love,
Else might I think that Clarence Edwards brother,
Were but a fained friend to our proceedings,
But welcome sweet Clarence my daughter shall be thine.
And now what rests but in nights coverture,
Thy brother being carelessly encamped,
His soldiers lurking in the town about,
And but attended by a simple guard,
We may surprise and take him at our pleasure,
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy,
Then cry king Henry with resolved minds,
And break we presently into his tent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why then let us on our way in silent sort,
For Warwike and his friends God and saint George.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This is his tent, and see where his guard doth
Stand, Courage my soldiers, now or never,
But follow me now, and Edward shall be ours.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Warwike, a Warwike.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and Gloster and Hastings flies.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Richard and Hastings let them go, here is the
Duke.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The Duke, why Warwike when we parted
Last, thou calledst me king?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye, but the case is altered now.
When you disgraced me in my embassage,
Then I disgraced you from being king,
And now am come to create you Duke of Yorke,
Alas how should you govern any, kingdom,
That knows not how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Well Warwike, let fortune do her worst,
Edward in mind will bear himself a king.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then for his mind be Edward Englands king,
But Henry now shall wear the English crown.
Go convey him to our brother archbishop of Yorke,
And when I have fought with Penbrooke and his followers,
I will come and tell thee what the lady Bona says,
And so for a while farewell good Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What follows now, all hitherto goes well,
But we must dispatch some letters to France,
To tell the Queen of our happy fortune,
And bid her come with speed to join with us.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye that is the first thing that we have to do,
And free king Henry from imprisonment,
And see him seated in his regal throne,
Come let us haste away, and having past these cares,
I will post to Yorke, and see how Edward fares.

div2.stage: Enter Gloster, Hastings, and sir William Stanly.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Lord Hastings and sir William Stanly,
Know that the cause I sent for you is this.
I look my brother with a slender train,
Should come a-hunting in this forest here .
The Bishop of Yorke befriends him much,
And lets him use his pleasure in the chase,
Now I have privily sent him word,
How I am come with you to rescue him,
And see where the huntsman and he doth come.

sp.speaker: Hunts
sp.l: This way my Lord the dear is gone.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: No this way huntsman, see where the
Keepers stand. Now brother and the rest,
What, are you provided to depart?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, the horse stands at the park corner,
Come, to Linne and so take shipping into Flanders.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Come then: Hastings, and Stanlie, I will
Requite your loves. Bishop farewell,
Shield thee from Warwikes frown,
And pray that I may repossess the crown.
Now huntsman what will you do?

sp.speaker: Hunts
sp.l: Marry my Lord, I think I had as good
Go with you, as tarry here to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Come then let us away with speed.

div2.stage: Enter the Queene and the Lord Riuers.

sp.speaker: Riuers.
sp.l: Tell me good madam, why is your grace
So passionate of late?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why brother Riuers, hear you not the news,
Of that success king Edward had of late?

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: What? loss of some pitched battle against Warwike,
Tush, fear not fair Queen, but cast those cares aside.
King Edwards noble mind his honours doth display:
And Warwike may loose, though then he got the day.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If that were all, my griefs were at an end:
But greater troubles will I fear befall.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: What, is he taken prisoner by the foe,
To the danger of his royal person then?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Aye, there is my grief, king Edward is surprised,
And led away, as prisoner unto Yorke.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: The news is passing strange I must confess:
Yet comfort yourself, for Edward hath more friends,
Than, Lancaster at this time must perceive,
That some will set him in his throne again.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: God grant they may, but gentle brother come,
And let me lean upon thine arm a while,
Until I come unto the sanctuary,
There to preserve the fruit within my womb,
King Edwards seed true heir to Englands crown.

div2.stage:
Enter Edward and Richard, and Hastings with a
> troope of Hollanders.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thus far from Belgia have we past the seas,
And marched from Raunspur haven unto Yorke:
But soft the gates are shut, I like not this.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sound up the drum and call them to the walls.

div2.stage: Enter the Lord Maire of Yorke upon the wals.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: My Lords we had notice of your coming,
And that is the cause we stand upon our guard,
And shut the gates for to preserve the town.
Henry now is king, and we are sworn to him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Why my Lord Mayor, if Henry be your king,
Edward I am sure at least, is Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: Truth my Lord, we know you for no less.

sp.speaker: Edw
sp.l: I crave nothing but my Dukedom.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But when the Fox hath gotten in his head,
He will quickly make the body follow after.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Why my Lord Mayor, what stand you upon points
Open the gates, we are king Henries friends.

sp.speaker: Mair.
sp.l: Say you so, then I will open them presently.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: By my faith, a wise stout captain and soon persuaded.

div2.stage:
The Maire opens the dore, and brings the
> keies in his hand.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: So my Lord Mayor, these gates must not be shut,
But in the time of war, give me the keys:
What, fear not man for Edward will defend
the town and you, despite of all your foes.

div2.stage:
Enter sir Iohn Mountgommery with
drumme and souldiers.

sp.l: How now Richard, who is this?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Brother, this is sir Iohn Mountgommery,
A trusty friend unless I be deceived.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome sir Iohn. Wherefore come you in arms?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: To help king Edward in this time of storms,
As every loyal subject ought to do.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thanks brave Mountgommery,
But I only claim my Dukedom,
Until it please God to send the rest.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Then fare you well? Drum strike up and let us
March away, I came to serve a king and not a Duke.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Nay stay sir Iohn, and let us first debate,
With what security we may do this thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: What stand you on debating, to be brief,
Except you presently proclaim yourself our king,
I will hence again, and keep them back that come to
Succour you, why should we fight when
You pretend no title?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Fie brother, fie, stand you upon terms?
Resolve yourself, and let us claim the crown.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I am resolved once more to claim the crown,
And win it too, or else to loose my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Aye now my sovereign speaketh like himself,
And now will I be Edwards Champion,
Sound Trumpets, for Edward shall be proclaimed.
Edward the fourth by the grace of God, king of England
and France, and Lord of Ireland, and whosoever gainsays king Edwards right: by this I challenge him to
single fight, long live Edward the fourth.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live Edward the fourth.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: We thank you all. Lord Mayor lead on the way.
For this night we will harbour here in Yorke,
And then as early as the morning sun,
Lifts up his beams above this horizon
We will march to London, to meet with Warwike:
And pull false Henry from the Regal throne.

div2.stage:
Enter Warwike and Clarence, with the Crowne, and
then king Henry, and Oxford, and Summerset,
and the yong Earle of Richmond.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus from the prison to this princely seat,
By Gods great mercies am I brought
Again, Clarence and Warwike do you
Keep the crown, and govern and protect
My realm in peace, and I will spend the
Remnant of my days, to sin's rebuke
And my Creators praise.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Clarence agrees to what king Henry likes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord of Summerset, what pretty
Boy is that you seem to be so careful of?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: And it please your grace, it is young Henry,
Earl of Richmond.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Henry of Richmond, Come hither pretty Lad.
If heavenly powers do aim aright
To my divining thoughts, thou pretty boy,
Shalt prove this Countries bliss,
Thy head is made to wear a princely crown,
Thy looks are all replete with Majesty,
Make much of him my Lords,
For this is he shall help you more,
Than you are hurt by me.

div2.stage: Enter one with a letter to Warwike.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What Counsel Lords, Edward from Belgia,
With hasty Germaines and blunt Hollanders,
Is past in safety through the narrow seas,
And with his troops do march amain towards
London,
And many giddy people follow him.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: It is best to look to this betimes,
For if this fire do kindle any further,
It will be hard for us to quench it out.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: In Warwike shire I have true hearted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war,
Them will I muster up, and thou son Clarence shalt
In Essex, Suffolke, Norfolke, and in Kent,
Stir up the knights and gentlemen to come with thee.
And thou brother Montague, in Leister shire,
Buckingham and Northampton shire shalt find,
Men well inclined to do what thou commands,
And thou brave Oxford wondrous well beloved,
Shalt in thy countries muster up thy friends.
My sovereign with his loving Citizens,
Shall rest in London till we come to him.
Fair Lords take leave and stand not to reply,
Farewell my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell my Hector, my Troy's true hope.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Lords, let us meet at Couentrie.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Seize on the shamefast Henry,
And once again convey him to the Tower,
Away with him, I will not hear him speak.
And now towards Couentrie let us bend our course
To meet with Warwike and his confederates.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?
How far hence is thy Lord my honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Oxf post.
sp.l: By this at Daintrie marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Where is our brother Montague?
Where is the post that came from Montague?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I left him at Donsmore with his troops.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Say Summerfield where is my loving son?
And by thy guess, how far is Clarence hence?

sp.speaker: Sommer.
sp.l: At Southham my Lord I left him with
His force, and do expect him two hours hence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then Oxford is at hand, I hear his drum.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: See brother, where the surly Warwike mans the wall.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O unbid spite, is spotful Edward come!
Where slept our scouts or how are they seduced,
That we could have no news of their repair?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Warwike wilt thou be sorry for thy faults,
And call Edward king and he will pardon thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Nay rather wilt thou draw thy forces back?
Confess who set thee up and pulled thee down?
Call Warwike patron and be penitent,
And thou shalt still remain the Duke of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I had thought at least he would have said the king.
Or did he make the jest against his will.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It was Warwike gave the kingdom to thy brother.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Why then it is mine, if but by Warwikes gift.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye but thou art no Atlas for so great a weight,
And weakling, Warwike takes his gift again,
Henry is my king, Warwike his subject.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I prithee gallant Warwike tell me this,
What is the body when the head is off?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alas that Warwike had no more foresight,
But whilst he sought to steal the singleton,
The king was finely fingered from the deck?
You left poor Henry in the Bishops palace,
And ten to one you will meet him in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: It is even so, and yet you are old Warwike still.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O cheerful colours, see where Oxford comes.

div2.stage: Enter Oxford with drum and souldiers and al crie,

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The Gates are open, see they enter in,
Let us follow them and bid them battle in the streets.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No, so some other might set upon our backs,
We will stay till all be entered, and then follow them.

div2.stage: Enter Summerset with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Summerset, Summerset, for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Two of thy name both Dukes of Summerset,
Have sold their lives unto the house of Yorke.
And thou shalt be the third if my sword hold.

div2.stage: Enter Montague with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Traitorous Montague, thou and thy brother
Shall dearly aby this rebellious act.

div2.stage: Enter Clarence with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And lo where George of Clarence sweeps
Along, of power enough to bid his brother battle.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Clarence, Clarence, for Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Et tu Brute, wilt thou stab Caesar too?
A parley sirrah to George of Clarence.

div2.stage:
Sound a Parlie, and Richard and Clarence whispers togither,
and then Clarence takes his red Rose out of his
hat, and throwes it at Warwike.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Come Clarence come, thou wilt if Warwike call.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father of Warwike, know you what this means?
I throw mine infamy at thee,
I will not ruinate my father's house,
Who gave his blood to lime the stones together,
And set up Lancaster. Thinkest thou
That Clarence is so harsh unnatural,
To lift his sword against his brothers life,
And so proud hearted Warwike I defy thee,
And to my brothers turn my blushing cheeks?
Pardon me Edward, for I have done amiss,
And Richard do not frown upon me,
For henceforth I will prove no more unconstant.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome Clarence, and ten times more welcome,
Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Welcome good Clarence, this is brotherly.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Warwike, wilt thou leave
The town and fight? or shall we beat the
Stones about thine ears?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why I am not cooped up here for defence,
I will away to Barnet presently,
And bid thee battle Edward if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yes Warwike he dares, and leads the way,
Lords to the field, saint George and victory.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and then enter Warwike wounded.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ah, who is nigh? Come to me friend or foe,
And tell me who is victor Yorke or Warwike?
Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,
That I must yield my body to the earth.
And by my fall the conquest to my foes,
Thus yields the Cedar to the axes edge,
Whose arms gave shelter to the princely Eagle,
Under whose shade the ramping Lion slept,
Whose top branch overpeered Jove's spreading tree.
The wrinkles in my brows now filled with blood,
Were likened oft to kingly sepulchres.
For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?
And who durst smile, when Warwike bent his brow?
Lo now my glory smeared in dust and blood,
My parks my walks, my manors that I had,
Even now forsake me and of all my lands,
Is nothing left me but my bodies length.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Ah Warwike, Warwike, cheer up thyself and live,
For yet there is hope enough to win the day.
Our warlike Queen with troops is come from France,
And at South-hampton landed all her train,
And mightst thou live then would we never fly.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why then I would not fly, nor have I now,
But Hercules himself must yield to odds,
For many wounds received, and many mo repaid,
Hath robbed my strong knit sinews of their strength,
And spite of spites needs must I yield to death.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Thy brother Montague hath breathed his last,
And at the pangs of death I heard him cry
And say, commend me to my valiant brother,
And more he would have spoke and more he said,
Which sounded like a clamour in a vault,
That could not be distinguished for the sound,
And so the valiant Montague gave up the ghost.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?
And live we how we can, yet die we must.
Sweet rest his soul, fly Lords and save yourselves,
For Warwike bids you all farewell to meet in Heaven,

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Come noble Summerset, let us take our horse,
And cause retreat be sounded through the camp,
That all our friends that yet remain alive,
May be awarned and save themselves by flight.
That done, with them we will post unto the Queen,
And once more try our fortune in the field.

div2.stage: Enter Edward, Clarence, Gloster, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thus still our fortune gives us victory,
And girts our temples with triumphant joys
The big boned traitor Warwike hath breathed his last,
And heaven this day hath smiled upon us all,
But in this clear and brightsome day,
I see a black suspicious cloud appear
That will encounter with our glorious sun
Before he gain his easeful western beams,
I mean those powers which the Queen hath got in France
Are landed, and mean once more to menace us.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Oxford and Summerset are fled to her,
And it is likely if she have time to breath,
Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: We are advertised by our loving friends,
That they do hold their course towards Townburie.
Thither will we for willingness rids way,
And in every county as we pass along,
Our strengths shall be augmented.
Come let us go for if we slack this fair
Bright Summers day, sharpe winters
Showers will mar our hope for hay.

div2.stage: Enter the Queene, Prince Edward Oxford and Summerset, with drum and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Welcome to England, my loving friends of France,
And welcome Summerset, and Oxford too.
Once more have we spread our sails abroad,
And though our tackling be almost consumed,
And Warwike as our maine mast overthrown,
Yet warlike Lords raise you that sturdy post,
That bears the sails to bring us unto rest,
And Ned and I as willing Pilots should
For once with careful minds guide on the stern,
To bear us through that dangerous gulf
That heretofore hath swallowed up our friends.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: And if there be, as God forbid there should,
Amongst us a timorous or fearful man,
Let him depart before the battles join,
Lest, he in time of need entice another,
And so withdraw the soldiers' hearts from us,
I will not stand aloof and bid you fight,
But with my sword press in the thickest throngs,
And single Edward from his strongest guard,
And hand to hand enforce him for to yield,
Or leave my body as witness of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Women and children of so high resolve,
And Warriors faint, why it were perpetual
Shame? O brave young Prince, thy
Noble grandfather doth live again in thee,
Long mayst thou live to bear his image,
And to renew his glories.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: And he that turns and flies when such do fight,
Let him to bed, and like the Owl by day
Be hist, and wondered at if he arise.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: My Lords, Duke Edward with a mighty power,
Is marching hitherwards to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: I thought it was his policy, to take us unprovided,
But here will we stand and fight it to the death.

div2.stage: Enter king Edward, Cla. Glo. Hast. and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: See brothers, yonder stands the thorny wood,
Which by Gods assistance and your prowess,
Shall with our swords ere night be clean cut down.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Lords, Knights and gentlemen, what I should say,
My tears gainsay, for as you see, I drink
The water of mine eyes. Then no more
But this. Henry your king is prisoner
In the tower, his land and all our friends
Are quite distressed, and yonder stands
The Wolf that makes all this,
Then on Gods name Lords together cry saint George.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Saint George for Lancaster.

div2.stage:
Alarmes to the battel, Yorke flies, then the chambers be
discharged. Then enter the king, Cla and Glo. and the rest,
& make a great shout, and crie, for Yorke, for Yorke, and
then the Queene is taken, and the prince, and Oxf. and Sum.
and then sound and enter all again.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lo here a period of tumultuous broils,
Away with Oxford to Hames castle straight,
For Summerset off with his guilty head.
Away I will not hear them speak.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: For my part I will not trouble thee with words.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.l: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my death.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now Edward what satisfaction canst thou make,
For stirring up my subjects to rebellion?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Speak like a subject proud ambitious Yorke,
Suppose that I am now my father's mouth,
Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,
Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee,
Which traitor thou wouldst have me answer to.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O that thy father had been so resolved:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: That you might still have kept your
Petticoat, and never have stolen the
Breech from Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Let Aesop fable in a winters night,
His currish Riddles sorts not with this place.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: By heaven brat I will plague you for that word.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Aye, thou wast borne to be a plague to men.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: For Gods sake take away this captive scold.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay take away this scolding Crooktbacke rather,

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Peace wilful boy, or I will tame your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Untutored lad thou art too malapert.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I know my duty, you are all undutiful.
Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George,
And thou misshapen Dicke, I tell you all,
I am your better, traitors as you be.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Take that, the likeness of this railer here .

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O kill me too.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Marry and shall.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Hold Richard hold, for we have done too
much already .

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why should she live to fill the world with words?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What doth she swooned? make means for
Her recovery?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother,
I must to London on a serious matter,
Ere you come there, you shall hear more news.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: About what, prithee tell me?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The Tower man, the Tower, I will root them out

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ah Ned, speak to thy mother boy? ah
Thou canst not speak.
Traitors, Tyrants, bloody Homicides,
They that stabbed Caesar shed no blood at all,
For he was a man, this in respect a child,
And men never spend their fury on a child,
What is worse than tyrant that I may name,
You have no children Devils, if you had,
The thought of them would then have stopped your rage,
But if you ever hope to have a son,
Look in his youth to have him so cut off,
As Traitors you have done this sweet young prince.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away, and bear her hence.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Nay never bear me hence, dispatch
Me here , here sheath thy sword,
I will pardon thee my death. Wilt thou not?
Then Clarence, do thou do it?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By Heaven I would not do thee so much ease.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Good Clarence do, sweet Clarence kill me too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Aye, but thou usest to forswear thyself,
It was sin before, but now it is charity.
Where is the Devil's butcher, hard-favoured Richard,
Richard where art thou? He is not here ,
Murder is his alms deed, petitioners
For blood he never put back.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away I say, and take her hence perforce.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: So come to you and yours, as to this prince.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Clarence, whither is Gloster gone?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: Marry my Lord to London, and as I guess, to
Make a bloody supper in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: He is sudden if a thing come in his head.
Well, discharge the common soldiers with pay
And thanks, and now let us towards London,
To see our gentle Queen how she doth fare,
For by this I hope she hath a son for us.

div2.stage: Enter Gloster to king Henry in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good day my Lord. What at your book so hard?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord. Lord I should say rather,
It is sin to flatter, good was little better,
Good Gloster, and good Devil, were all alike,
What scene of Death hath Rosius now to act?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Suspicion always haunts a guilty mind.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The bird once limed doth fear the fatal bush,
And I the hapless male to one poor bird,
Have now the fatal object in mine eye,
Where my poor young was limed, was caught and killed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why, what a fool was that of Creete?
That taught his son the office
Of a bird, and yet for all that the poor
Fowl was drowned.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I Dedalus, my poor son Icarus,
Thy father Minos that denied our course,
Thy brother Edward, the sun that seared his wings,
And thou the envious gulf that swallowed him.
O better can my breast abide thy daggers point,
Than can mine ears that tragic history.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why dost thou think I am an executioner?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: A persecutor I am sure thou art,
And if murdering innocents be executions,
Then I know thou art an executioner.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thy son I killed for his presumption.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hadst thou been killed when first thou didst presume,
Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine,
And thus I prophesy of thee.
That many a Widow for her husband's death,
And many an infants water standing eye,
Widows for their husbands, children for their fathers,
Shall curse the time that ever thou wert borne.
The owl shrieked at thy birth, an evil sign,
The night Crow cried, aboding luckless tune,
Dogs howl and hideous tempests shook down trees,
The Raven rooked her on the Chimney's top,
And chattering Pies in dismal discord sung,
Thy mother felt more than a mothers pain,
And yet brought forth less than a mothers hope,
To wit: an undigest created lump,
Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree,
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast borne,
To signify thou camest to bite the world,
And if the rest be true that I have heard
Thou camest into the world

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Die prophet in thy speech, I will hear
No more, for this amongst the rest, was I ordained.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Aye and for much more slaughter after this.
O God forgive my sins, and pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What? will the aspiring blood of Lancaster
Sink into the ground, I had thought it would have
mounted,
See how my sward weeps for the poor kings death.
Now may such purple tears be always shed,
For such as seek the downfall of our house.
If any, spark of life remain in thee,
Down, down to hell, and say I sent thee thither.
I that have neither pity, love nor fear.
Indeed it was true that Henry told me of,
For I have often heard my mother say,
That I came into the world with my legs forward,
And had I not reason think you to make haste,
And seek their ruins that usurped our rights?
The women wept and the midwife cried,
O Iesus bless us, he is borne with teeth.
And so I was indeed, which plainly signified,
That I should snarl and bite, and play the dog.
Then since Heaven hath made my body so,
Let hell make crooked my mind to answer it.
I had no father, I am like no father,
I have no brothers, I am like no brothers,
And this word Love which greybeards term divine,
Be resident in men like one another,
And not in me, I am myself alone,
Clarence beware, thou keptest me from the light
But I will sort a pitched day for thee.
For I will buzz abroad such prophesies,
As Edward shall be fearful of his life,
And then to purge his fear, I will be thy death.
Henry and his son are gone, thou Clarence next,
And by one and one I will dispatch the rest,
Counting myself but bad, till I be best.
I will drag thy body in another room.
And triumph Henry in thy day of doom.

div2.stage:
Enter king Edward, Queene Elizabeth, and a Nurse
with the young prince, and Clarence, and Hastings, and others.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Once more we sit in Englands royal throne,
Repurchased with the blood of enemies,
What valiant foemen like to Autumn's corn,
Have we mowed down in tops of all their pride?
Three Dukes of Summerset, threefold renowned
For hardy and undoubted champions.
Two Cliffords, as the father and the son,
And two Northumberlands, two braver men
Never spurred their coursers at the trumpets sound.
With them the two rough Bears Warwike and Montague,
That in their chains fettered the kingly Lion,
And made the Forest tremble when they roared,
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat,
And made our footstool of security.
Come hither Besse, and let me kiss my boy,
Young Ned, for thee, thine Uncles and myself,
Have in our armours watched the Winters night,
Marched all afoot in summer's scalding heat,
That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace,
And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will blast his harvest if your head were laid,
For yet I am not looked on in the world.
This shoulder was ordained so thick to heave,
And heave it shall some weight or break my back,
Work thou the way, and thou shalt execute.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Clarence and Gloster, love my lovely
Queen,
And kiss your princely nephew brothers both.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The duty that I owe unto your, Majesty,
I seal upon the roseate lips of this sweet babe.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thanks noble Clarence worthy brother
thanks.

sp.speaker: Gloster
sp.l: And that I love the fruit from whence thou
Sprangest, witness the loving kiss I give the child.
To say the truth so Iudas kissed his master,
And so he cried all hail, and meant all harm.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Now am I seated as my soul
delights,
Having my countries peace, and brothers loves.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What will your grace have done with Margaret,
Ranard her father to the king of France,
Hath pawned the Cyssels and Ierusalem,
And hither have they sent it for her ransom.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away with her, and waft her hence to France,
And now what rests but that we spend the time,
With stately Triumphs and mirthful comic shows,
Such as befits the pleasures of the Court.
Sound drums and Trumpets, farewell to sour annoy,
For here I hope begins our lasting joy.
